Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will partially support the 2018 Field of Dreams Conference, to be held at the Renaissance St. Louis Airport Hotel, in St. Louis, MO, from November 2-4, 2018. The Field of Drams Conference is organized by the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences (Math Alliance), an organization whose goal is to increase the number of students from backgrounds underrepresented in the mathematical sciences who earn doctorates in those fields. Approximately 200 students will attend the conference, and about 75% of those will be underrepresented minorities. The conference coordinates with the Alliance's Facilitated Graduate Admissions Process (F-GAP), which has helped place approximately 70 Alliance Scholars in graduate programs each of the last five years with very good retention to this point. So, the conference is an essential part of a program to produce a more diverse professional mathematical workforce. In addition, there are events at the conference which assist faculty in mentoring practices and help academic departments transform their cultures to be more supportive of student success.

The Field of Dreams conference has several purposes, including: providing information about all aspects of the mathematical sciences professions to students wishing to pursue doctoral studies; providing information about summer research programs and opportunities at the NSF-funded Mathematical Sciences Institutes; facilitating appropriate placement of Alliance students in graduate programs; providing professional development in mentoring and cultural competence for our Alliance faculty; and serving as a clearinghouse for employment opportunities for new Alliance doctoral recipients. More information about the alliance is available at www.mathalliance.org. The 2018 Field of Dreams Conference program, and material from previous years' conferences, are available at https://mathalliance.org/field-of-dreams-conference/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 Field of Dreams Conference was held November 2-4, 2018, at the Renaissance Airport Hotel in St. Louis, MO. There were 377 registered conference participants: 189 undergraduate and terminal MS Alliance Scholars, 130 faculty mentors, 39 Ph.D. students, and 19  participants were exhibitors, representatives of NSF Funded Math Science Institutes, Alliance Board members and Staff, and outside speakers.

We attach the agenda to the Final Report, and summarize some highlights. There were three major addresses during the meeting. On Friday, November 3, Cristine Villalobos, University of Texas R?o Grande Valley, delivered our 3rd  annual Connections lecture, titled Optimization of LPDA Antennas with Axial Twist.   On Saturday November 3, The Math Sciences Lecture was given by Peter Sarnak, Princeton University, on Navigating PU(2) with Golden Gates, and the annual Banquet Keynote address was delivered by Rodrigo Ba?uelos, Purdue University, titled Outcomes of small probabilities: Personal reflections of a first generation college graduate.   For the second year, we had was  short (20 minute) What Is... talks presented by representatives of NSF funded Math Sciences Institutes, each being a brief introduction to a topic in a mathematical science. There were six such talks on Saturday, November 3. The titles and speakers  for these six talks can be viewed in the  agenda.  We also held our first Career Fair, specifically to connect Math Alliance Schilars who have earned doctorates with potential employers. The Graduate Fair (Saturday afternoon) featured 68 tables,  Other important conference activities included panels for students on various aspects of preparing for graduate school, and panels for faculty on mentoring practices. For the first time, many of the sessions were documented by video recording, and these are publicly available at the Math Alliance Youtube Channel (there is a link in the final report).

The primary objective of this conference, as part of the work of the Math Alliance in general, is to produce more doctorates in the mathematical sciences among groups which are traditionally underrepresented in those fields. The conference supported by this award contributed to accomplishing that objective by exposing our predoctoral Alliance Scholars (70-80% of whom are underrepresented minorities) to the opportunities available to them in a broad range of disciplines in which their preparation in quantitative fields is desirable. The conference also plays an important role in F-GAP, a program which works to place our students into graduate programs where they can succeed. There were 142 participants in the 2018-19 F-GAP program, an increase of 30.2% over 2017-18. At the 2018 conference, 108 F-GAP students were in attendance, which was an increase of 21.3% over the previous year. Extrapolating from the survey responses we've received from this group, we expect about 110 F-GAP students were admitted to graduate programs in the mathematical sciences. Based on the outcomes of previous F-GAP cohorts, we expect their retention rate within these programs to be very high. During the Field of Dreams Conference F-GAP students consult one on one with their faculty facilitator, and have the opportunity to speak with representatives of graduate programs the student, facilitator, and undergraduate mentor, have determined are a good fit for the student's goals and academic background. We have identified 98 Ph.D.s received by students who were Alliance Predoctoral Scholars (i.e., were Alliance Scholars prior to entering a Ph.D. program).  Only 8 of these 98  degrees was earned by students in the F-GAP program, because the first F-GAP students entered Ph.D. programs in 2014.  Thus expect the number of Alliance Scholar Ph.D.s to rise rapidly.
